title: Global E-waste Management Market to grow at 12.82% through 2023-28 to be valued at USD 122.48 Billion: Bonafide ... - GlobeNewswire
summary: The rapid expansion of the e-waste management market is driven by the increasing prevalence of electronic devices and the need for effective disposal methods. E-waste contains hazardous materials and valuable recoverable materials, prompting investment in innovative recycling technologies, including IoT, AI, and robotics. The article highlights global challenges and regulatory compliance for e-waste management while emphasizing the significant opportunity for companies in the recycling industry to benefit financially and support the circular economy.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the article discusses e-waste management practices that reduce environmental impacts by reclaiming and recycling valuable materials while safely disposing of hazardous substances.
business_innovation: TRUE, as the article describes advancements and new practices in e-waste management that differ significantly from previous processes, demonstrating improvement in efficiency and sustainability.
green_product: FALSE, because while the article addresses the management of e-waste, it does not specifically name a good or service that fits within the definition of a green product.
green_process: TRUE, since the article outlines innovative processes in e-waste management that minimize environmental impacts through advanced technologies and recycling methods.

title: Waste Expo Australia 2023: Advancing towards sustainable resource recovery - Waste Management Review
summary: Waste Expo Australia 2023 is set to take place in Melbourne on October 25-26, 2023, focusing on sustainable resource recovery management solutions. The event will gather waste management professionals and industry experts to discuss trends, challenges, and innovations while showcasing cutting-edge products and services. Keynote speakers and panel discussions will cover waste reduction, regulatory compliance, and circular economy opportunities, aiming to spark meaningful conversations within the industry.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the event promotes sustainable practices in waste management, aligning with the goals of reducing waste and carbon emissions.
business_innovation: FALSE, the article does not mention a specific product or business process introduced by a firm; it discusses an event rather than a commercial innovation.
green_product: FALSE, as the article does not explicitly describe any specific green product.

title: ElecSome brings PV upcycling to Victoria - Waste Management Review
summary: ElecSome is launching a pioneering upcycling facility in Victoria, Australia, to recycle solar panel waste into new materials for the construction industry, with a focus on sustainability. Their product, SolarCrete, uses glass fines from solar panels as a substitute for natural sand in concrete, aiming to reduce environmental impact and conserve natural resources. The initiative stems from a collaboration between local universities and businesses, addressing waste management and promoting a circular economy in solar energy. ElecSome plans to expand its operations across Australia with a nationwide collection network for end-of-life solar panels.
green_innovation: TRUE, because the innovation focuses on recycling solar panel waste into new products, significantly reducing environmental impact and promoting sustainable waste management.
business_innovation: TRUE, because it introduces a new upcycling process and product (SolarCrete) that differs significantly from previous practices in materials manufacturing and waste management.
green_product: TRUE, because SolarCrete is designed and produced in a way that significantly reduces environmental impact and utilizes recycled materials, aligning with the principles of a green product.
green_process: TRUE, because the dismantling and recycling approach used to transform solar panel waste minimizes environmental impacts and promotes sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities, 327390 - Other Concrete Product Manufacturing, 541715 - Research and Development in the Physical, Engineering, and Life Sciences (except Nanotechnology and Biotechnology), 236220 - Commercial and Institutional Building Construction
greenwashing: FALSE, because the article provides substantial evidence of environmentally responsible practices and innovations aimed at sustainability, rather than misleading claims.

title: Operators appointed for Vic container deposit scheme - Government News
summary: Victoria has announced the launch of its drink container recycling program, starting on November 1, which will involve over 600 independently operated collection points that provide a 10 cent refund for each deposited container. The program, managed by VicReturn and operated by companies such as TOMRA, aims to recycle beverage containers efficiently and reduce litter. The government plans to oversee the program, which is expected to promote recycling and divert significant amounts of waste from landfills. A survey indicated strong community support for returning containers for refund.
green_innovation: TRUE - This initiative promotes environmental sustainability by encouraging recycling, reducing litter, and managing waste effectively.
business_innovation: TRUE - The container recycling program represents a new or improved business process that significantly differs from previous waste management approaches in the region.
green_product: FALSE - The article does not discuss a specific product but rather focuses on a recycling scheme and its operational aspects.
green_process: TRUE - The recycling process outlined in the program minimizes environmental impacts by promoting the recovery and reuse of materials, thus supporting sustainability.
likely_naics_codes: Likely NAICS Codes: 562991 - Composting Facilities; 621910 - Ambulatory Health Care Services; 813312 - Environment, Conservation, and Wildlife Organizations; 562920 - Materials Recovery Facilities.
greenwashing: FALSE - The article presents a transparent and accountable recycling program funded by the beverages industry without misleading claims about environmental benefits, indicating it is not an example of greenwashing.

title: Top 10 Best Waste Management Companies In Europe 2023 - Inventiva
summary: The article discusses the importance of waste management in modern society, highlighting its impact on public health, environmental protection, resource conservation, energy generation, and economic benefits. It reviews several leading waste management companies in Europe, including their commitment to sustainability and innovative practices in handling waste through recycling and energy recovery. Companies like Veolia, SUEZ, Renewi, and others are noted for their efforts in minimizing environmental impacts while optimizing resource usage. The need for sustainable waste management practices is emphasized as essential for future generations.
